abstracts.cdata!:
The Governance and Opportunity
            Development Policy Loan in Tunisia was rated as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory
            and the borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            There were eight lessons learned.  (1) Multi-sector
            multi-donor DPLs are an effective instrument to consolidate
            the policy dialogue, which is especially valuable in a
            transition environment. (2) The Bank's bold and
            strategic decision to focus its program in the immediate
            aftermath of the revolution has helped accomplish
            significant results in Tunisia in a very short time. (3)
            That said, the reforms program supported by the GO DPL was
            perhaps overly ambitious, given institutional capacity
            constraints. (4) Single-tranche DPL operations are not well
            suited for ambitious institutional reforms. (5) An efficient
            government coordination mechanism with strong leadership and
            clear responsibility is critical to monitor and sustain the
            implementation of an ambitious reforms program. (6)
            Technical assistance is critical, especially in new policy
            areas where the government does not have
            expertise/experience and where an innovative approach is
            required to change administrative practices. (7) A quality
            M&E framework is needed to effectively assess the
            progress and outcomes of reforms. (8) The location of the
            TTL and most of the team in the field, particularly for a
            complex operation involving other co-financiers based in the
            field, is essential to efficiently and continuously interact
            with the authorities and donors.
